replies.context: You're right, though perhaps without fully realizing the additional technical hurdles that presents.  But I have long thought that Nasa underestimates the importance of public engagement, it's not some minor detail, not a web page design job for a summer student.  Scientist are good at what they do but they tend to hive off funding and PR to other departments.  They need to bake that into the design criteria.  A return to crewed exploration beyond LEO would probably solve the problem, but in the meantime, they need to remember - we're the paying customers - and we want a show.

context: But affordable housing will have to wait.

affordable housing exists...
In rural Arkansas?   That's cause no real humans live there!

No there are a lot of places that can be found - granted may not be where you want to be but definitely not urban Arkansas also may not be the house you dream of but a roof is a roof and this is coming from a person who was homeless with a wife and Kid for  a few months... We also survived about 18 years on one income and that time when we were homeless was because the house we were is was unsafe and caught fire... If you are doing life right and well, homelessness is usually because of a direct action of the person whom is homeless...

Well, that makes one of us.
also mechanical heart and plenty of other innovative products and concepts that would have never been considered if they weren't problems that needed to be solved to explore space.
I don't want entitlements either. Young people can't afford $500,000 starter houses.

Then don't feel like you have to buy $500k starter houses. There are plenty of places in the country where young people can work and afford to live. It is not my responsibility to buy them houses in expensive places.

Most people aren't looking for $500K starter homes, but you know what $500K will get you in my neighborhood?   A home very similar to mine.  I paid less than half of that AND it's paid off too.  (well...less than half if you don't count the interest, but overall still less than $500K).

I used to SHARE a $300 a month apartment with a Chemical Engineer and like he always said, "Weed will get you through times of no money better than money will get you through times of no weed."   Just a little stoner humor there, but aside from the CRIME and the lack of heat during winter, sharing a $300 a month apartment wasn't so bad. I'm still 95% sure the burglar was the maintenance man in that apartment building - no way to prove it and it's not like the cops care about people who live in such low-rent housing.

unless you are in NY or California not certain where there are starter homes for that amount - plenty new ones being built in Texas that are between $180K - $350K many used homes going for less than that.

I remember what my parents paid for the home in Texas that I spent most of my childhood in. It was far less than even $100K.  Now?   It's well over a MILLION and that's downplaying the value quite a bit.  I haven't looked in a few years, but easily $1.5 million, probably more. It was nothing fancy - just a ranch-style house about a mile from where my father went camping as a Boy Scout when he was a kid - because when he was a kid that whole area was undeveloped.

Most people can't afford to live in houses like that.  I know I can't.  I'd love to live in that house, but my parents sold it and built their own house that cost far more money.  Maybe I'll inherit that.  LOL, no.  I don't want my parents house. I mean it's nice and everything, but I'd have to move back to Texas.  Still, I'd rather move back there than California or NY.  I actually lived in NY for a month. It was NOT NYC, so It was okay.  I saw .38 Special...in upstate NEW YORK.  Good show.  I'd go again if they were the same band they were back then. Too bad they're not.

Yeah my mom purchase the house we lived in for about 40K in a subdivision in north Harris county in the late '80's and it will probably go for 200K now but starter cars weren't 20K to 60K back then either. Our current house was purchased in '91 at 42K and is worth 187K now... wouldn't catch me in NY or California sorry you feel so out of place here in Texas this is my home and don't have any reason to leave it.
Housing the homeless would be too, well, Christian.   We can't have that....
I would help anyone who needs it AND would take my help. If you walked by and gave $1000 to a homeless person, it almost certainly would not go towards rent.
Christians provide plenty of housing for the homeless time for the secularists to step up and pay their fare share - seeing how many christian pay taxes and tithe seems they are helping more...
Jimmy Carter and Habitat for Humanity do a lot for homeless people, but Republicans despise them.

I am republican and volunteer for habitat - most of my church does also and yes they are republican so not sure you know what you are talking about. 

- Carter was a horrible president - may be a good person but wouldn't vote for him or anyone like him...

Me too, but dig this:   McMansions are far more profitable than affordable housing.  The city where I live doesn't want a bunch of homeless people. We've already got a few just like every other city in the US. We've had them for YEARS.  Some of them look like refugees from the meat plant in the next county.  Seriously, they hire a lot of actual refugees and of course some of them are illegal.  There's nothing they can do about that unless they start paying a living wage.  Americans won't work in the plants. It's hard work. They use E-Verify but they still get raided by ICE and before they used E-Verify they got fined MILLIONS by the EEOC for trying too hard to keep illegals out of the work force.

There are some unscrupulous lenders who will give loans to people they know can't pay them off. The whole idea is to collect as much money as they can and foreclose on the home and sell it again which is far more profitable than steady income from low-rent housing.  They do the same thing with car loans too - even the leased ones.

There are 3 tiers of housing in my neighborhood. There are apartments, townhomes/condos and McMansions. There are no homeless people in my part of town. They're downtown or hanging out in front of stores that we would NEVER walk to. I don't give them money, but sometimes I buy them food.

We are not talking about war, we are talking about NASA.   War and combat is whole other issue.. keep focused.. this is about NASA.  Spending billions, producing nothing and giving the American people no value except excuses on why it takes 2+ decades to build a capsule others built in a few years and for WAY WAY LESS money.

The fact of the matter is, that scientific advancement produces all kinds of inventions that benefit humanity, except the war industry, whose ONLY purpose is to destroy and kill. And THAT is the industry the US spends more on than the top 10 countries COMBINED.

buwahahahaha.. Nice try to obfuscate there.   Velcro?   Man are you really going to try and make bull up now for your argument?   Velcro was the invention of a Swiss engineer, Georges de Mestral In 1941, it was NOT invented by NASA.

Let's say even if NASA invented something in the past..  You think that justifies the billions spent today of MY money?   I SAID LAST 2-3 DECADES of spending.  We already know they can't seem to even build a spacecraft.. They have been trying since 2006 with Orion.

So I say the same to you.. NAME ONE THING MY TAXDOLLARS have brought out of NASA in the last 2 decades...  ONE THING that makes the BILLIONS spent worth it.

No, you're a Neanderthal and if everyone had your attitude we'd still be living in hovels on some feudal lord's land working like slaves.

I would say caves, but there's not nearly enough caves for the world's population even 1000 years ago.

We wouldn't have clean water, electricity or even steam engines. The boats would all use sails or oars and we'd fight with swords, spears, and bow and arrows. We wouldn't even have gunpowder because nobody would have ever figured it out.

We would be devastated by disease and starvation which would at least keep the population low so there would be more caves for those of us lucky enough to get one.  I'd much rather live in a cave than a hut made of twigs. At least it would be warmer in winter and cooler in summer and I'd have shelter from the rain and snow and wind.  Hopefully it wouldn't flood. That's sometimes a problem in caves.
Love it!
